summary: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of North Carolina today entered a final judgment against Harold Clyde Griffin, Jr., a convicted felon who was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Charlotte, North Carolina, alleges that, on the night of 30 December 2015, several individuals decided to go out partying.  According to the complaint, the defendants decided to drive around the area where Stokley's body lay, and then demanded that Skinner drive him back to his home. The complaint further alleges that after learning that the items recovered from the scene had been fired from a gun, the defendant asked Skinner to check the gun and to see if the bullets were fired from the same gun.  As alleged, the complaint alleges that when confronted by a "dark-skinned man with dreads," the defendant replied, “Instead of one body it will be three.”  The complaint charges that, based upon her examination of the gun, she did not meet the reliability standards for expert opinion under Rule 702.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Griffin consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders him to pay a civil penalty of $10,000.  He also agreed to be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company for five years.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for North Carolina announced criminal charges against Griffin.  On May 9, 2018, the Honorable Kathleen M. Gibson of the U. S. District court for the Eastern District of South Carolina entered a judgment against Griffin, ordering him to be permanently enjoined from future violations of Rule 10a-5, ordering that he pay a $10 million civil penalty, and imposing a $25,000 civil penalty.  Judge Gibson also ordered that the SEC pay a penalty of a total of $1.5 million.  To settle the case, the court also ordered the defendants to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, and ordered them to pay civil penalties of $20,000 each.  Finally, Judge Gibson issued an order suspending the defendants from appearing or practicing before the SEC as an expert in the field of forensic firearms examination.  She also ordered all defendants to submit written testimony in the form of an opinion that satisfied the reliability and accuracy requirements of Rule 702, ordering them to each submit a written opinion to the SEC that satisfied those requirements.
